title: Texas A&M tied for most Quad 1A wins in the SEC before facing Alabama
description: Texas A&M enters the new week with three all-important Quad 1A wins, tied with Tennessee and Kentucky for the most in the SEC.
fullText:
Texas A&M's (17-4, 7-1 SEC) NCAA Tournament resume is looking better every week, as the Aggies are riding a four-game winning streak in SEC play after defeating Georgia on the road 92-77 behind another balanced scoring effort resulting in five players scoring in double figures, led by senior forward Rashaun Agee's 18 points, 15 rebounds and seven assists, recorded his tenth double-double of the season.

Under first-year head coach Bucky McMillan, the Aggies aren't lacking confidence, and after losing a close game to SMU on the road during the latter half of non-conference play, Texas A&M has lost just one game since, dropping a double-overtime road matchup vs. Tennessee, which should have gone the other way if free throws and questionable officiating weren't an issue.

Leading the SEC at 7-1, three of Texas A&M's conference wins are Quad 1A victories, which, according to the NCAA NET rankings, are wins against teams ranked in the top 15 ranked teams at home, top 25 on a neutral court, and top 40 on the road in the NET standings. Tied with Tennessee and Kentucky, here are the SEC teams with more than one Quad 1A win.

Over the next four games against Alabama (road), Florida (home), Missouri (road), and Vanderbilt (road), Texas A&M will have three Quad 1A opportunities, and winning one, or two of these tough matchups would likely guarentee the Aggies an at-large bid in the NCAA Tournament, especially given the fact that McMillan's squad is a perfect 12-0 in Quad 3 and Quad 3 games.

After Florida blew out Alabama 100-77 on Sunday night, Texas A&M has a chance to take advantage of the Crimson Tide's short turnaround before playing on Wednesday, but needs to play with the same mentality, and shoot at least 45% from the field, and hit free throws to have a chance at pulling off the upset.

Contact/Follow us @AggiesWire on X (formerly Twitter) and like our page on Facebook to follow ongoing coverage of Texas A&M news, notes and opinions. Follow Cameron on X: @CameronOhnysty.

This article originally appeared on Aggies Wire: Texas A&M basketball's three Quad 1A wins tied for most in the SEC

title: Vanderbilt vs Ole Miss men's basketball game moved to Nashville
description: Winter storms force SEC to flip Vanderbilt-Ole Miss men's basketball game sites. Commodores to play Rebels in Nashville on Saturday.
fullText:
Thanks to Winter Storm Fern, the SEC flipped the script on No. 18 Vanderbilt men's basketball and Ole Miss, announcing Jan. 29 that the game scheduled for Jan. 31 at SJB Pavilion in Oxford, Mississippi, will now be played at 5 p.m. on the same date at Memorial Gymnasium in Nashville.

The conference also announced that the matchup between Tyler Tanner and Mark Byington's Commodores and the Rebels scheduled for March 4 in Nashville will be played in Oxford.

Winter storms that have caused heavy damage in the Oxford area have forced the school to close through Feb. 8. Many in the area are without power or water and there are hazardous, icy road conditions, many downed trees and power lines and fluctuating temperatures.

All tickets bought for the game scheduled for March 4 in Nashville will be valid for the Jan. 31 game. Vanderbilt said fans should see updated tickets in their accounts as soon as Jan. 29.

Tickets also can be purchased at VUCommodores.com.

Paul Skrbina is a sports enterprise reporter covering the Predators, Titans, Nashville SC, local colleges and local sports for The Tennessean. Reach him at pskrbina@tennessean.com and on the X platform (formerly known as Twitter) @paulskrbina.

This article originally appeared on Nashville Tennessean: Vanderbilt-Ole Miss men's basketball game moved to Nashville

title: Duke Miles injury update, Vanderbilt basketball guard out vs Kentucky
description: Duke Miles is out for Vanderbilt basketball vs Kentucky, according to the SEC injury report.
fullText:
Vanderbilt basketball will be without a key piece as it takes on Kentucky for a matchup at Memorial Gymnasium on Jan. 27.

Duke Miles is out for the contest due to an undisclosed issue, according to the SEC's game day injury report.

Miles is No. 15 Vanderbilt's second-leading scorer this weekend. He averages 16.6 points per game and is also second on the team in assists with 77 after transferring from Oklahoma.

The Commodores (17-3, 4-3 SEC) are already thin in the backcourt with Frankie Collins also out. Collins has not played since a December matchup with Memphis.

Miles being out may necessitate more playing time for Jaylon Dean-Vines, Mike James or Chandler Bing, none of whom have played a significant amount of minutes this season. Vanderbilt has struggled to get production out of its bench this season.

For Kentucky, Kam Williams, Jaland Lowe and Jayden Quaintance are out.

Aria Gerson covers Vanderbilt athletics for The Tennessean. Contact her at agerson@gannett.com or on X @aria_gerson.

This article originally appeared on Nashville Tennessean: Duke Miles of Vanderbilt basketball injury update vs Kentucky

title: SEC Seeks Fresh Pathway to Advance in Stalled Adani Fraud Case
description: After failing to serve Gautam Adani with a legal summons for more than a year, the US Securities and Exchange Commission wants a judge to clear a way for the agency to advance with its fraud case against the Indian billionaire.
fullText: MarketsBy Patricia Hurtado and Tom SchoenbergSaveAfter failing to serve Gautam Adani with a legal summons for more than a year, the US Securities and Exchange Commission wants a judge to clear a way for the agency to advance with its fraud case against the Indian billionaire. The SEC asked US District Judge Nicholas Garaufis in Brooklyn, New York, on Wednesday to let it use alternative measures to ensure that Adani and his nephew Sagar Adani — who both reside in India — are formally made aware of the legal action against them. Generally, such litigation can’t proceed in the US until the defendants have been properly served with the complaint.

title: ESPN predicts outcome for Auburn basketball's game at Ole Miss
description: Does ESPN favor Auburn basketball getting its first SEC road win of the season on Tuesday?
fullText:
The Auburn Tigers will look to get their first road win in the SEC on Tuesday night when they travel to face the Ole Miss Rebels. Auburn will also look to improve its conference record to 3-3 after starting conference play with a 1-3 record. Ole Miss enters the game with a record of 11-7, and they are 3-2 in the SEC. Auburn got a bounce-back win on Saturday, defeating South Carolina 71-67 to improve their overall record to 11-7.

The ESPN Matchup Predictor gives Auburn a slight edge in this game, with a 53.9% chance of winning. They have Ole Miss at 46.1% chance of winning.

Auburn had to hold on late to gain its victory over South Carolina on Saturday night. Filip Jovic had his best game as an Auburn Tiger, scoring 23 points and was 9 of 12 from the floor. Jovic also pulled down six rebounds to lead the Tigers to a much-needed victory. Auburn needed the performance with Keyshawn Hall and Tahaad Pettiford struggling once again. Auburn's two stars combined for 17 points and were 4 of 15 on field goals. It was the second consecutive game where they both struggled to find their offense. The Tigers will need to play better in this road matchup.

Like Auburn, Ole Miss started their SEC schedule 0-2 after losses to Oklahoma and Arkansas. They followed that up with three straight wins against Missouri, Georgia, and Mississippi State. The Rebels do rank last in the SEC, scoring just 76 points per game. However, they are third in the conference, allowing 70.8 points per game, and have held their opponents to 42% shooting. The Rebels' leading scorer is forward Malik Dia with 14.2 points per game. He has struggled over the previous two games and has not scored over double figures. Their other option is senior guard AJ Storr, who is averaging 13.3 points per game. He had 17 points in the Rebels' 68-67 win over rival Mississippi State on Saturday.

The Auburn Tigers will face the Ole Miss Rebels on the road for a Tuesday night contest scheduled for a start time of 8 p.m. CT. The game will be broadcast by ESPNU.

Contact/Follow us @TheAuburnWire on  X (Twitter), and like our page on Facebook to follow ongoing coverage of Auburn news, notes, and opinions. You can also follow Phillip on Twitter @PJordanSports

This article originally appeared on Auburn Wire: Auburn basketball vs Ole Miss prediction by ESPN

title: Cardinals urged to replace Kyler Murray with 30-TD SEC star
description: The Arizona Cardinals are undergoing some big changes this offseason, so why not start over at quarterback as well?
fullText:
Cardinals urged to replace Kyler Murray with 30-TD SEC star originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Arizona Cardinals are undergoing some big changes this offseason.

The team endured a terrible season in 2025 and moved on from head coach Jonathan Gannon as a result. Now, the team is looking for a new coaching staff and could potentially be looking for a new quarterback as well.

Kyler Murray, who's been the team's passer since 2019, played in just five games this year. Even when Murray played, the results were underwhelming, and his massive contract isn't conducive to being a backup.

As a result, Jacob Infante of PFSN recently published a full seven-round mock draft that has the Cardinals taking a rookie quarterback.

Infante has the Cardinals waiting until the third round and selecting Ole Miss quarterback Trinidad Chambliss. Chambliss is currently in a legal battle to get one more year of college eligibility, but the expectation is that he will enter the draft.

Regarding Chambliss and the Cardinals, Infante offered the following:

There are valid concerns with Trinidad Chambliss: he has an average arm, he’s undersized, and he started at the D1 level for only one year. That said, there’s also a lot to like. He’s a naturally accurate passer with impressive anticipation behind his throws, and he came in clutch in key situations for Ole Miss this year.

Someone will take a chance on him early, given how many NFL teams need quarterbacks this offseason.

As Infante mentioned, Chambliss only has one year of starting experience at the D1 level, but that one year was incredibly impressive.

In 2025 with Ole Miss, Chambliss threw for 3,937 yards with 22 touchdowns and just three interceptions. The quarterback also rushed for 527 yards and eight touchdowns, accounting for 30 total scores in 13 starts.

Before 2025, Chambliss played at DII Ferris State, where he won two national championships. The quarterback isn't the biggest, but he is bigger than Murray, and has a strong arm and nice mobility.

It wouldn't be easy to move on from Murray, though. The only way the team wouldn't have to eat a ton of dead money is if they traded Murray after June 1. In that scenario, the team would free up about $35 million in cap space.

description: A high-performance, modular web framework for Go with integrated observability. 8.4M+ req/sec, 119ns latency, 16 bytes/request.
fullText:
Modular. Observable. Cloud-native. Production-ready.

From zero to production-ready API in under a minute.

Everything you need to build, deploy, and operate web services at scale.

8.4M+ requests per second with 119ns latency. Radix tree router with Bloom filter optimization.

Functional options everywhere. Configure observability, OpenAPI, health checks, and more—all the same way.

Truly modular. Use what you need. Each package works standalone—no framework lock-in.

Batteries-included web framework

Request binding (JSON, form, query)

Struct validation with JSON Schema

Automatic OpenAPI 3.0/3.1 generation

Named after the wild rhubarb plant that thrives at 1,500–3,000 meters in harsh mountain terrain of Iran. 
 It withstands extreme conditions, yet provides nourishment for centuries.

title: Texas A&M HC Bucky McMillan previews crucial road test vs. Texas
description: Coach Bucky previews the Texas matchup, stressing focus, composure, and execution as Texas A&M looks to rebound and earn a key SEC win in Austin.
fullText:
The Texas A&M basketball team enters rivalry weekend looking to reset after a grueling double‑overtime loss to Tennessee. It was a tough shooting night across the board, and the Aggies will aim to get back on track Saturday when they travel to Austin to face the Texas Longhorns.

For head coach Bucky McMillan, it marks his first experience in the Lone Star Showdown — and an opportunity to do something no A&M coach has accomplished since 2001: win in Austin. He understands exactly what this rivalry means to Aggies everywhere, but he’s also pushing his team to stay grounded and avoid getting swept up in the noise.

" ...our players got to block out all the noise and just know that our success going to in this game is going to be on their ability to focus on the things that equate to winning basketball"

It’s not about minimizing the rivalry, McMillan emphasized, but recognizing the bigger picture. The SEC grind is long, and every conference game carries weight. That perspective has been reinforced by A&M’s 3–1 start in league play — a stretch that has boosted the team’s confidence despite the close calls.

"it's been great and that's why I say we can get caught up like a game slips away here or there where you're right there to win it. But there's also a lot of games on the flipside of that that we executed and won,"

A win on Saturday would move the Aggies to 4–1 in SEC play, a meaningful early‑season marker that could pay dividends later in the year. For McMillan, the message remains simple: play their style, trust their habits, and let the chips fall where they may.

Below, you can watch the full press conference with Coach Bucky.

Texas A&M will face the Texas Longhorns in Austin at the Moody Center on Saturday, January 17, at 5 p.m. CT. The matchup will air on ESPN.

Contact/Follow us @AggiesWire on X and like our page on Facebook to follow ongoing coverage of Texas A&M news, notes, and opinions. Follow Jarrett Johnson on X: @whosnextsports1.

This article originally appeared on Aggies Wire: Watch: A&M coach Bucky McMillan previews road matchup against Texas

title: Student-loan borrowers behind on payments are getting a major break, the US education secretary says
description: Education Sec. Linda McMahon told reporters that wage garnishment for defaulted student-loan borrowers has "been put on pause for a bit."
fullText:
Student-loan borrowers in default might not face smaller paychecks — yet.

Education Sec. Linda McMahon told reporters at a visit to a Rhode Island school earlier this week that wage garnishment for defaulted student-loan borrowers has been put on pause.

When asked by a reporter how the garnishment would impact borrowers, McMahon responded: "Well, actually, there is a pause."

"We've now collected about $500 million," McMahon said. "The next phase to go into a place was garnishment, and that's been put on pause for a bit."

The Department of Education did not make a formal announcement on this pause and did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Business Insider.

It follows an announcement from the department in December saying that it would begin sending wage garnishment notices to about 1,000 defaulted borrowers in early January, with the intent to increase the scale of those notices each month.

In May, the department resumed collections on defaulted student loans after a five-year pause. Defaulting on student loans, which typically happens after 270 days of missed payments, can have significant consequences in addition to wage garnishment, including seizure of federal benefits like Social Security and tax refunds.

Aissa Canchola Bañez, policy director at advocacy group Protect Borrowers, said in a statement that the administration's plans to garnish wages "would have been economically reckless and would have risked pushing nearly 9 million defaulted borrowers even further into debt."

title: Where to watch Georgia vs. LSU gymnastics today: Channel, live stream, time, TV schedule for SEC meet
description: Georgia hosts LSU in an SEC gymnastics meet. Here's how to watch all the action with TV channel and live stream information.
fullText:
Where to watch Georgia vs. LSU gymnastics today: Channel, live stream, time, TV schedule for SEC meet originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

SEC gymnastics is in full swing, and it continues with a Friday night showdown in Athens. Georgia hosts LSU in a top-10 meet.

The No. 8 Bulldogs are fresh off a win over Ohio State where they posted a 197.000, their highest opening score since 2007. All-American Lily Smith earned three event titles at the meet on bars, beam and floor.

The Tigers, ranked second in the nation, finished tied for first at the Sprouts Collegiate Quad. Their 197.500 finish tied it up with Oklahoma, who ultimately won the meet on a tiebreaker. Regardless, it was a confident start to the season for LSU who recorded its second-best season opening score in program history.

As college gymnastics enters another week, the competition only gets better from here. What will this latest matchup hold?

Here's how you can watch all the action with TV channel and live stream information for Georgia vs. LSU.

Georgia vs. LSU gymnastics will be broadcast on SEC Network. Cord-cutters can live stream the meet on Fubo.

title: Josh Pate declares whether Big Ten has overtaken SEC in college football moving forward
description: The Big Ten is on the verge of winning its third straight national title. Josh Pate recognizes it and has weighed in on where it sits against the SEC.
fullText:
Josh Pate declares whether Big Ten has overtaken SEC in college football moving forward originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

If it were up to college football podcaster and analyst Josh Pate, the Big Ten-SEC debate as to which conference holds the cards isn't even close.

Pate said on a recent edition of "Josh Pate's College Football Show" that the Big Ten deserves the same respect, if not more, than the SEC in this current era of college football.

“The SEC is lagging behind the Big Ten, at the top," Pate said. "I would even venture to suggest the middle-tier now is at least comparable if not slightly lagging behind. That’s probably where my perception has changed of late, moreso than at the top. So I’m not beating that drum.”

Pate made an interesting follow-up point: it doesn't even matter that the Indiana Hoosiers are currently the class of the league. It's the psychological framework about what makes those players more polished than those from the SEC. And it's greater than just mental and physical toughness, Pate said.

More: Todd McShay passionately defends Dante Moore's decision to return to Oregon Ducks

“Maybe the average Big Ten player is wired a little bit differently, maybe they focus a little more on the football aspect, the mean-and-potatoes aspect of football, instead of the more highlight-ish, branding aspect of football,” Pate said.

That "wired" approach is the most unique part. It can't be taught. It can't be studied.

“If you think that’s ridiculous, it’s because it is,” Pate said. “But that’s been standard practice in the SEC for awhile. And I don’t find it to be the case in the Big Ten.”

More: Inside the special moment Indiana's Curt Cignetti will never forget

Whether the narrative returns in favor of the SEC is unclear, but right now, the Big Ten can keep chasing excellence.

Entering Monday night's game, a potential Hoosiers victory over the Miami Hurricanes may further validate Pate's argument while the SEC watches from the sidelines.
